urlLink Miss. L has come up with a brilliant idea to avoid post-breakup phone calls: “I got an idea for a website. Two, actually: "dontcallhim.com" and "dontcallher.com" You go there, and read a manifesto on why you should not call the person you want to call but shouldn't (like your ex). The original idea came when my friend Jeremy got three calls in one night from a girl he'd JUST started dating and I said "Dude, she shouldn't call you, she should call me, and I'll tell her why she shouldn't call you." (The original idea was for operators to be standing by to tell people how to play their current romantic situation. 1-900-LUVADVICE.) But back to the website: maybe there would be little tabs you could click on that corresponded to your situation. "Because he's an asshole", "Because of that restraining order", "Because it's only been twenty minutes", "Because you already left her three messages." Etc.”

We ain't no "kingpin," but we're more badass than NY. NJ ranks 16th in survey of corruption convictions "Its corruption index was 3.57, based on federal prosecutions. Mississippi topped the list, at 7.48. By - New Jersey is more corrupt than most states, but hardly the most corrupt, according to a new survey. New Jersey was ranked the 16th most corrupt state in terms of federal corruption convictions per 100,000 residents from 1993 to 2002. The report, "Public Corruption in the United States," was researched by Corporate Crime Reporter, a Washington-based newsletter, and published Friday. New Jersey has a well-chronicled history that led the Almanac of American Politics to once brand it "the nation's most corrupt state." But based on New Jersey's 307 corruption convictions in U.S. District Courts in Newark, Camden and Trenton in 10 years and its 2002 population of 8.6 million, the new study gave the state a corruption index of 3.57. That was less than half the 7.48 rate of the study's corruption kingpin, Mississippi. New York barely made the graft top 10, at 4.56, and Pennsylvania was 14th, at 3.78." Steve Strunsky Associated Press NEWARK, N.J.

Idiot kid crawls into crane game, Fox gets the story. urlLink WBAY-Coverage You Can Count On: Boy Crawls Into Arcade Machine, Becomes Trapped A seven-year-old boy got in a fix in Sheboygan when he crawled into a supermarket's stuffed animal game machine and couldn't get back out. Shift Commander Mark Zittel of the Sheboygan Fire Department says that when rescuers arrived, the boy was sitting among the stuffed animals inside the glass enclosure. The stuffed animals are prizes that can be hooked with a crane-like device. Zittel says the boy's father was three feet away at a pay phone, and when he turned around the child was in the machine. Zittel says the boy somehow crawled through about an eight-inch-by-ten-inch opening. The boy stayed calm and didn't panic as firefighters responded to the Piggly Wiggly store and got a locksmith to open the main loading door. The process took about an hour. Zittel says the boy was not injured or traumatized, but he desperately needed to use the bathroom by the time he was freed.

The hotttest class @ NSU this spring... urlLink Hip Hop Dancing NDRF0109 A 6 session(s). Wed, 8:00-9:50 PM, beg. February 4. $220.00 Register: Non-Credit Jorge Pabon (Popmaster Fabel) Learn two of the most exciting dance forms of the seventies funk movement: Popping and Locking. When these dances debuted on Soul Train, they took America by storm and influenced many early Hip Hop dancers. Popping/Boogaloo style is a robotic dance form featuring both fluid and sharp angular movements that create illusions. Locking is a funky dance that incorporates points, wrist rolls, hand claps, and locks. We cover the foundations of the "electric boogaloo" style: the "twist-o-flex," "walk outs," and the "Egyptian twist," as well as components of Locking, including "skeeter rabbits," "scooby doos," and "scoo bot hops." Beginners welcome. Wear loose comfortable clothing and footwear that doesn't have too much grip/traction. Class meets at a studio to be announced; please call (212) 229-5883 after Jan. 4 for location. (0.0 credits)

Thurston Moore remembers "alternative rock" and the presence of Kurt Cobain. urlLink When Kurt died, a lot of the capitalized froth of alternative rock fizzled. Mainstream rock lost its kingpin group, an unlikely one imbued with avant-garde genius, and contemporary rock became harder and meaner, more aggressive and dumbed down and sexist. Rage and aggression were elements for Kurt to play with as an artist, but he was profoundly gentle and intelligent. He was sincere in his distaste for bullyboy music — always pronouncing his love for queer culture, feminism and the punk rock do-it-yourself ideal. [ urlLink NYT ]

urlLink While Bush is in the convention center Sept. 2, the Secret Service wants all Amtrak, NJTransit and Long Island Rail Road Service to cease, the Daily News has learned. The scrum over New York security emerged as officials in Boston revealed they plan to close two transit hubs for a full week, starting three days before the start of the Democratic Convention on July 23. The worries over the raillines and convention safety come a few weeks after train bombings in Madrid killed 191 people. [Daily News Via urlLink Productshopnyc ] How about, oh I don’t know, lets worry about all the people in attendance at these events that could get injured or perhaps the commuters who rely on trains to get to their jobs, instead of halting transportation just to save those running for president. If the commuters have the guts to get on a train everyday, to suspend their fear, then the presidential hopefuls should do the same.

MTV is looking to cash in on the homowave of ’04 with a urlLink 24 gay network, Logo . Minimal backlash is expected. Tom Freston, the chairman of MTV Networks, the division of Viacom that will run Logo, said company executives understood that some people were uncomfortable with gay men and lesbians. But he cited polls that he said indicated increasing levels of tolerance and acceptability for gay people. "We don't expect any huge backlash," Mr. Freston said. Adding, “I mean people really dig that Will & Grace show.” In addition to broadening minds, the station is also hoping, to reach a segment of the population that is desirable to many advertisers because of its more than $400 billion in buying power. Nothing like purchasing your way into mainstream acceptance. [NYT] For your favorite gay, lesbian or tranny parents, urlLink Rosie O’Donnell is attempting to start a mag for non-het families. Starbucks Baristas in Midtown are attempting to unionize. They are fighting for more cash, hours and better working conditions. [via urlLink information underload ] urlLink Starbucks workers start at $7.75 an hour and eventually receive raises amounting to merely a few cents. Starbucks has also developed a scheme whereby all Baristas work on a part-time basis and are not guaranteed any amount of hours per week thus making it exceedingly difficult for workers to budget for necessities like rent, utilities, and food. I agree retail workers deserve more; I support their efforts, though some of the arguments presented in this article were a bit weak. urlLink Starbucks workers serve an enormous volume of beverages, many of them extremely hot... Ahhh, the plight of the Barista. Yes, getting $7.75 sucks, Yes, working an inconsistent schedule sucks, but don't take a job serving coffee and expect not to get burned. It happens. It's also important to note that employees, in addition to their shit pay, receive tips and those working 20 hours a week or more are eligible for health benefits. It's crap, but it's still better than other urlLink retail outfits .

I saw The Shins a million years ago (last Sunday) at the Bowery Ballroom. I have been meaning to write up some highlights, though I never feel I can do live events any justice. I will however, share some fantastic moments with you, including The Shins cover of ‘Holy Diver,’ my successful attempt at hitting on a girl and Moby’s baldhead. If urlLink Lloyd Dobbler was standing outside my window right now, radio above head, he would be playing “ urlLink Clark Gable .” Though seeing as this is reality and not a Cameron Crowe film, I am left to fend off my desire to romanticize about everything outside of myself. If anything I figured out one thing, my ideal man is definitely a combination of urlLink Bukowski and Dobbler. Which means I am really into eternally conflicted alcoholics. Something about Bukowski is just so hot though, perhaps it is the overt misogyny, the talk of sleeping up against a woman’s ass. There is an obvious celebration of detachment in fantasying about fucking someone so far from everything I actually believe in. But there is also detachment in dreaming of the unrealistic wide eyed romanticism that Dobbler presents. It’s the night in shining armor syndrome. I am still waiting to be saved by a kid with a boom box or willingly used by an abusive addict. It’s this dream of “true romance” that I thought I was impervious to, but have somehow become obsessed with. It makes me cringe. I use to sob over being alone, now I just get frustrated, annoyed that I am still looking beyond everything I have, wishing I had someone to take summer bike rides with. Why is romance with others so alluring, yet romance with the self so difficult?

Sophomore year of high school Melissa was a self proclaimed “indie rock goddess.” She shaved her head, dotted her “I”s with “X”s, spun urlLink Jackpot incessantly and was invited to join her first and last band, ever. Her friends urlLink Emily (mLe) and Katie (k8e) were searching for a drummer for their yet unnamed female rock n’ roll outfit. The three ladies eventually called themselves The Flirttarts. It was a short, but brutal affair; the band was rife with lesbian drama, Heavens to Betsy covers and riot grrrl posturing. This is their story. Soon after Melissa joined the group, Katie was “kicked out” after missing a few practices due to her underage drinking problem and “other friends.” Emily and Melissa made a halfhearted attempt to find a new bassist. They crafted a sign out of notebook paper and black sharpie for the local supermarket: “Riot Grrrls looking for grrrl who enjoys ovary centric rock and Bikini Kill to play bass in go nowhere band. Grrrl Power!” No one called. They continued on as a two-piece operation. The remaining Tarts practiced endlessly in Melissa’s attic, recording songs into her alarm clock/radio/bootleg-taping device. They bickered over the spelling of their name (Emily wanted one “t” in flirttarts, Melissa wanted two) and “the direction” the band was heading. Melissa had always secretly wanted to be in a joke band, (and still secretly desires it) but Emily was a bit more serious. She wanted to sing about “real issues,” like rape and stuff. The Tarts managed to play in public only once, at a VFW in Redbank NJ. They were last on the bill and by the time they set up their shoddy operation, everyone had left, even the kid who had showed Melissa his nipple rings earlier in the evening. The Tarts massacred “Ax Man,” sloppily made it through one of their own jams and decided to end their three-song set with a handcrafted ditty about masturbation, sung off key and with a tambourine. It was obviously Melissa’s idea, and it was obviously awful. The Flirttarts broke up soon after. Emily went off to urlLink Lang to study hipsterdom in the big city and Melissa cast aside her Converse for Birkenstocks, Junior year and way too much Ani Difranco. Posthumously The Flirttarts were included on a DIY compilation tape, Quean Scream, manufactured out of some girl’s bedroom in San Pablo, California. (Copies are still available, all interested parties please inquire in the comments section.) Currently, Emily is unemployed and living in Queens making art, Melissa is a wage slave and avid alcoholic with a nice rack. This post inspired by urlLink essen west .

Even Slate hates King Arthur.... urlLink He fights against his own people because he considers Rome the fount of democracy, religious tolerance, and the credo that men (and women) control their own destinies. Given the bloody repression practiced by Rome at the time, this is moronic, but Arthur is not presented as a moron, merely a soldier who is a tad out of touch—as much of a bleeding-heart liberal-humanist as a man who has lopped off thousands of insurgents' limbs can be. ... urlLink King Arthur is profoundly stupid and inept, but it's an endless source of giggles once you realize that its historical revisionism has nothing to do with archeological discoveries and everything to do with the fact that no one at Disney would green-light an old-fashioned talky love triangle with a hero who dies and an adulterous heroine who ends up in a nunnery. Some say best review ever written!

Man I really love a good epic battle movie, I love them so much that I went to see urlLink King Arthur last night. Now melodrama is welcome, in fact it’s needed in films like this, but sometimes it can kill a potentially good scene. Bruckheimer is a pro at doing this through overusing special effects. Worst ever is this battle scene on ice, the Knights (good guys) are banking on the Saxons’s (bad guys) ignorance. The ice beneath the enemy’s feet is going to give. The tension builds, the armies move in, there are all these cool arrows swooshing through air noises and then… … long computerized close-ups of ice cracking. CRAP! Where did the characters go? I want to see some fucking struggle, some action, some swords clanking, not a bunch of Vikings falling to a cold watery death. Damn you Bruckheimer for raping me at the box office once again! (and Pirates was so good, so good!) I know epic battle movies are based on these ridiculous effects, I go there hoping for it, I just don’t want to be reminded during the film. Some of the effects employed in the Lord of The Rings trilogy were effing awful, but Jackson always seemed to pull them off by distracting me with an affinity for the characters. Even Zwik managed to draw me in with his fancy Cruise driven urlLink Last Samurai . But King Arthur, I say eh. On the positive side, some of the battles, especially those with fire, were awesome, urlLink Keira Knightly was steller as Guinevere (though that’s probably because I like to see a woman with battle blood on her face), urlLink Sir Lancelot could easily replace a urlLink Stroke if needed and although King Arthur himself left much to be desired, the hottie with the bird (Mads Mikkelsen) was everything an epic battle hero should be, sexy and dirty. I leave you with his photo… urlLink

urlLink Ivory's a champ. Body Glitter exists because of one woman. That woman is Ivory. We worked at Girl Scout camp together years ago. Last January when I was up there for a reunion, I found out, through a mutual coworker, that urlLink Ivory had a live journal . I wouldn’t say reading it was a life altering experience, but it did convince me to start this blog. Last weekend while at camp again (or more like visiting the bar near camp), I ran into Ivory and thanked her for the inspiration, we did some shots and I got tanked. Before I got tanked though, Ivory managed to deliver the best quote I’ve ever heard. I had moved our conversation from blogs into talk of Dungeons and Dragons. (I want to know how to craft a character sheet. It’s a really dope skill to have.) Occasionally Ivory plays D&D with her boyfriend, though she gets annoyed when they play together. She continued on to explain the root of her dissatisfaction and inadvertently dropped the best quote ever, “My boyfriend never lets me be Dungeon Master.” Fucking genius. I know my delivery was shit but it’s a brilliant quote anyway. I just hope this grievance doesn’t lead to a break up. Ivory + her boyfriend, whose name I don’t know = T.L.F.

In the past 6 days I have been pulled over 3 times. Last Thursday I noticed that my front headlight was out on my car. I had been meaning to take it in for servicing anyway, so I called my favorite mechanic Neil, who wears the most boss Velcro shoes, to make an appointment. I got the machine. The answer phone told me Neil was on vacation until Monday. He was probably off with the wife and kids having a grand time. I let it go. First Offense: Friday night while making a trek to urlLink Magnolia with urlLink Kim , urlLink Kate and urlLink Jeremy , I was pulled over for speeding. The cop gave me a ticket for my burned out headlight and advised me to “slow it down.” I thanked him and continued on. Second Offense: I called Neil on Monday as planned and made an appointment to bring my car in on Wednesday morning. I never do anything in the morning that requires getting up before 8:20, so I made arrangements to drop my vehicle off Tuesday night after Sons & Daughters. urlLink Sara would follow me to the urlLink mechanic . Tuesday on my way there, driving exactly, if not below the posted speed limit, I was pulled over again. I waited for a while until the cop decided to approach my vehicle. He eventually sauntered up to the car, passed my window and checked my headlights. I watched him through the windshield as he examined the single beam of light. There was obviously no need for this show; he knew the light was out, I knew the light was out; I just wanted to get to it. He broke the silence with the usual line, “Do you know why I pulled you over?” I shot him an authoritative “yes” and explained my situation gesturing toward Sara sitting in her car in a nearby parking lot. Like a jealous lover, he asked me where I had been. I lied and told him I was coming from my friend’s house, forgetting I was wearing a yellow, as he called it, “club” bracelet. I remained calmed and played it off like the “club” I had been to meant nothing to me. In a monotone voice I said, “oh yeah I went to a show.” I knew what he was getting at with these questions though, so I added, “but I wasn’t drinking.” My answers satisfied him and he took my license and registration back to his cruiser for a good time. He found nothing incriminating on my record and told me I was free to go. I dropped my car off as planned and Sara gave me a lift home. Third Offense: During this minor car crisis my sister graciously loaned me her vehicle to ensure that I would have transportation. While driving her car I was pulled over a third time. It was no longer funny, I was definitely cursing. I knew I was not speeding; I had stopped all speeding Friday. I was still rifling through my sister’s glove compartment, looking for her insurance card when the cop came to the window and delivered the standard line. This time I had no idea what I was stopped for. Apparently, my sister had failed to renew her registration. Great. The cop asked me if my record was clean and I told him yes, I figured if it wasn’t I would’ve been issued a ticket during my last incident. He collected the nesscary idetification and went to his vehicle. After running my information he came back to the car, cocky, puffed up with power and said, like, the dick that he was, “your record isn’t clean, you have two points.” I tried to defend myself saying, “I forgot about them”, adding, “they are from a long time ago. He cut me off, “well I’m not gonna lecture you.” He then launched into a diatribe on checking the paperwork in a car before borrowing it, closing with, “I’m not going to give you a ticket but tell whoever this car belongs to, to renew the registration.” The guy was still a fucker. Obviously this all could have been worse if I was issued three tickets, luckily I wasn’t. This whole saga was mostly funny, until it got old and not so funny anymore. As of right now I haven’t been pulled over since Wednesday. But I’ll keep you posted.

I want to try to avoid using the word awesome when writing about Sons & Daughters @ urlLink Northsix last night. I don’t think I can resist it though, it was awesome. Normally when I go to see a band I don’t know that well, I get bored, stare off into space and dream about my future ex-husbands. S&D, however, did not allow me to indulge in such behavior, I was mesmerized by their stage presence and their effing great tunes. I missed S&D when they opened for Franz Ferdinand a few months back (because I didn’t attend those shows), so all I had to go on was a song from urlLink Vague Space and a few mp3 clips from urlLink their website . I thought I would be in for a night of slow but charming folk. I was not, however, prepared to shake it so much. Every song was a hoe down, I wanted to grab a partner and circle round. (The square dance is coming back by the way, Body Glitter proclaimed this first. And it will totally happen because it would be both fun and ironic. See urlLink Karaoke resurgence .) Sons & Daughters played steady, dropping tracks like “Johnny Cash” on the crowd and coming back encore style with “Awkward Duet.” I was very satisfied and have since hunted down and purchased urlLink Love the Cup .
